Nurse Practitioners

Status: New Idea
by Agates317 on ‎06-07-2014 11:58 PM
I explored your website to complete an assignment as part of my degree to become a Nurse Practitioner. The articles I read talked only of speaking with your doctor about managing your diabetes. You do a great disservice to the 1,000's of nurse practitioners who provide competent, quality to health care to those with, or without, diabetes. I suggest that you substitute "doctor" for health care provider. A family nurse practitioner is able to guide patients through the diagnosis and management of their condition and a well-respected organization such as ADA can help promote this growing yet historical group of practitioners and encourage patients to trust them with their care. Thank you

Amber Gates, AGACNP AND FNP student
"They don't care how much you know until they know how much you care."
  • 3 Comments (3 New)
  • Permalink

Comments
by Carleen656 on ‎06-08-2014 10:58 AM
Options
  • Mark as Read
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

I'm all for progress but...  My three encounters with nurse practitioners were horrible and I will NEVER go to one again.

 

First time was for a routine gyne exam with no doctor ever seeing me. NP missed the fact that I did have issues that my doctor was tracking.

 

Second time was for a follow-up breast exam, again to follow an existing condition, and she never actually found the issue nor mentioned it.  Again no doctor ever saw me.

 

While these two encounters could have been life-threatening in the long-term, I did follow up with my physician and everything turned out well. It was a time factor, though, and could have had bad consequences.

 

Third time truely was life-threatening. The NP prescribed a skin cream that contained a medication I must never, never use as it interacts with my other meds.  I asked her what was in the cream and when she told me, I told  her that I cannot use it. She assured me that "this one's OK".  I did refuse the med but I told my doctor about it. He about went ballistic. 

 

These were three different NPs, not the same one.  Third time's the charm.  No more NPs for me.  My own opinion is that they are a danger to be avoided.

 

  • Permalink

I have had no problems when I have been seen by a NP. I have very high regards for their chosen profession.

 

James G

  • Permalink
by dw8888 on ‎06-15-2014 10:15 AM
Options
  • Mark as Read
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

Hi there NP!

I have had good and bad experiences with NPs.

But I also have had the same with Physicians.

In fact my daughter is an NP.

Neither is the point.

Why would I want to see an NP for my Diabetes? When I have to see the Doctor anyway as well as

a Certified Diabetic Educator. That's Three professionals, when I only need 2.

If you wish to compete with Doctors and CDEs for diabetic patients, then get certified as a CDE as well as your NP.  With the ability to write scripts, you can pretty much work independently of Drs careing for diabetics. Its a big growing market.  I think you would be a hugh asset to a practice.

 

Of course, you will have to do your own research regarding compensation.

 

Diabetics need dedicated health care professionals!   

Are you Up to this?

Announcements

Welcome to our Ideas area!

This area is for our users to share suggestions with us on how to improve and optimize the American Diabetes Association's web services. Please share your Ideas and vote for those of others if you like them.

Note: Posting an idea here does not guarantee implementation, but we will certainly read and weigh the merits of all submissions.
